instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi Team

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which had a lot of issues: No DCIN : fixed was <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> shorted to ground
Then <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground, fixed was <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> shorted to ground
Now the ISL doesn't turn it's pin 1 to ground to switch <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR>
PP3V42: OK 3,47V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 1,4V but slowly going to ground
Pin 2 <SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL>: fluctuating between 16,4V and 16,7V
Pin 3: OK 4V
Pin 14 <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> : 0V
Resistance 17/18 OK: 3,3 Ohms 27/28 20,2 Ohms

Now I'm suspecting the ISL.
Is there anything else to check before i replace the ISL

thanks

Finally I've replaced it and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12,56V

Now I've a quarter fan spin.....let me go throught it and check which rail is missing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Here are my mesurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 12,51
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> :3,471
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> :3,326

5V Rails:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>) : 4,997
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> : 4,994
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> : 0V
<SIGNAL>P5V_3V3_SUS_EN</SIGNAL> : 3,326v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> : 3,297V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> : 3,325v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> : 3,437V

3.3V Rails:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> :3,326V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> :0,6v BUT PULSE TO 3,3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> : 3,324v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> : 0v BUT PULSE TO 3,3v

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> VOLTAGES:

<SIGNAL>P5VS3_ENTRIP</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>P5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL>: 3,453V
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL>: 0,769V


<CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Level :
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> : PULSING TO 3,3v
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTC</SIGNAL> : 32KHZ OK
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_ENET_SYSCLK</SIGNAL> : PULSING
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: 3,436 OK
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> : 0V

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: Pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: Pulsing
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>: OK

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>: Pulsing

I've replaced <CAPACITOR>C3898</CAPACITOR> it was bad looking and bad value (2,5uF vs 4,7uF) , also replaced <RESISTOR>R5481</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5482</RESISTOR>.
Now I'm suspecting <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>: corroded or bad

Could you please give your feeling

THANKS

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Still a short somewhere, maybe 3v3 or 5v rail, board is cycling...if you found all that other stuff damaged/killed, this one might have several issues. Was this liquid or bad charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It look like that in fact it was liquid damaged

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5123</RESISTOR> was missing : THAT FIXED THE QUARTER FAN SPIN, it's directly involved in the SPI Bus
<CAPACITOR>C1713</CAPACITOR> was also missing
also i didn't reported it, but i had 2 brokens traces around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> one in the R17/18 loop and in the 27/28 loop.
Now had to put back every thing together to check if all the functions are fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So here are the last news:

When i've reassembled qll together, i had no chime, no display, fan increasing speed until it stoped, board overheating.
The overheqting was because <CHIP>U3890</CHIP> was shorted to ground, i revomed it and continued my troubleshooting without it as it's used for the thunderbolt.
at that point nothing overheating on the board but still same behavior regarding the fan ( increasing speed until it stops).
all my main power rails looked OK, then i checked the voltages <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> both were 0V with low resistance to ground.
I decided to remove <RESISTOR>R7510</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7520</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7550</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7640</RESISTOR> looking for a short to ground, nothing found but after replacing back all those 4 resistances the fan doesn't spin anymore but just a tiny pulse when the charger is plugged.
so i went throught all the rails again and this is what i have:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 12,56
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> :3,471
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> :3,326

5V Rails:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>) : 5,105
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> : 5,102
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> : 5,107V
<SIGNAL>P5V_3V3_SUS_EN</SIGNAL> : 3,326v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> : 3,296V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> : 3,325v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> : 3,437V

3.3V Rails:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> :3,326V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> :3,325v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> : 3,323v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> : 3,326v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> :3,320v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> : 1,798v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_DDR</SIGNAL> : 1,506 v


<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> VOLTAGES:

<SIGNAL>P5VS3_ENTRIP</SIGNAL>: 1,120V
<SIGNAL>P5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL>:3,453V
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL>: 0,769V


<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> :3,317v
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTC</SIGNAL> : 32KHZ OK / 0,417V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_ENET_SYSCLK</SIGNAL> : 3,314v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: 3,436 OK
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> : pulse to 0,49 then 0V

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 0,020V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 5,104V
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>: OK

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>: 3,306V

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL> : 1,505v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> : 0,014v with 54 ohms to ground when power and 4,5 Ohms to ground without power
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> : 0,001V with 5,9 ohms to ground with power and 2,1omhs without.
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> : 0,000v wtith 1,5 ohms to gound with power and 1,3 ohms without.

With <RESISTOR>R7640</RESISTOR> Removed:

Nothing on pin1 of L7630 mesured also with the scope.

<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> VOLTAGES:
CPUVCCIOS0_EN: 3,264V
PP5V_S0_CPUVCCIOS0: 5,103v
UGATE AND NGATE no signal on the scope except one pulse on UGATE
<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> replaced and still the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You are in S0 state but missing <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>.
You will not have <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> without It. 

Not sure but it looks like you are measuring resistance with power applied.

I don't have a board in front of me to compare but I think 4,5 ohms on the missing rail is low. If no short look around <CHIP>U7780</CHIP> see if voltage rails on pin 3, 4 and 6 are present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi Jadao,
thanks for your answer: apparently I have all the correct voltages around <CHIP>U7780</CHIP>, on pin 1 I have 1,057V, but if i mesure this rail around <CHIP>U5511</CHIP> for example I mesure 0,020V.
But what you asking me to mesure is <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_LDO</SIGNAL> which is different from <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> see page 7. Am I wrong?
Also I'm mesuring 362Ohms between those "2" rails.
I've noticed that i've forgot to put back <RESISTOR>R7640</RESISTOR> sorry.
Now it's done and the fan is spining but increases until it stops

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Oh sorry,  scrap this,  nothing to do with <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_LDO</SIGNAL>!
Your problem is <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>. Make sure by comparing with another 3115 there is no short on this rail. I can check resistance for you tomorrow.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> is suspect. There is low value resistors in <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> circuit, check them to make sur all ok.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
HI Team,

here are the last voltages mesured for this board, after ultrasonic cleaner, fan progressively spin to max speed, board not getting hot, no chime, smc re heated with flux, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, CPU and DDRVTT voltages:

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> : 1,802V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_DDR</SIGNAL> : 1,506
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> : 1,516v
<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> : 0v RESISTANCE TO GND 1,4KOHM
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> : 0,904v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> : 1,040v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> : 1,056V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_PCH_VCCADPLL</SIGNAL> : 1,059V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> : 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> : 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL> : 1,506V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCPQE</SIGNAL> : 1,056v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_CPU_VCCPLL_R</SIGNAL> : 1,796V

Can someone explain me how <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> are working please, i couldn't find the datasheet on google.
Should i suspect the SMC?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is not present so there must be a rail missing. PPVCORE is not involved in this, once <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> comes high then you need to worry about PPVCORE. Check voltages at <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>
